discussion.content:
How long it takes to close a work item: Cycle time

Cycle time measures the time it takes to complete a work item, from the moment work begins until it is completed (or closed).
The number of completed backlog items: Velocity

Velocity measures the amount of work completed during a sprint or iteration. It is typically used to track the number of completed backlog items.
How long it takes to restore failed services: Lead time

Lead time measures the total time from when an issue is identified (or work is requested) until it is resolved (such as restoring a failed service).

Cycle time measures how long it takes to close a work item (start to finish).

Velocity tracks the number of completed backlog items in a sprint.

Lead time measures how long it takes to restore failed services (issue identification to resolution).

discussion.content:
How long it takes to close a work item (Cycle Time):

 Widget Type: Query Tile or Chart for Cycle Time
 Details: Use the "Query Tile" widget to display the average cycle time for work items. You can create a query that calculates the time taken to close work items and visualize it using this widget.

The number of completed backlog items (Burndown):

 Widget Type: Burndown Chart
 Details: Use the "Burndown" widget to visualize the number of completed backlog items over a sprint or iteration. This chart effectively shows the progress toward completion of work.

How long it takes to restore failed services (Lead Time):

 Widget Type: Query Tile or Chart for Lead Time
 Details: Similar to cycle time, you can use a "Query Tile" or a custom chart to track the lead time for service restorations. This can be configured based on a query that measures the time from incident creation to resolution.

Cycle Time widget

2. The number of completed backlog items:
Velocity widget
Velocity: Measures the number of completed backlog items within a timeframe.
3. How long it takes to restore failed services:
Lead Time widget
Lead Time: Measures time from service failure to restoration.

Answer is correct.

- Subtract 2 datetimes gives a timespan : https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/kusto/query/datetime-timespan-arithmetic?view=microsoft-fabric. "One can subtract (but not add) two datetime values to get a timespan value expressing their difference."

The query you provided will return five columns in its output. Here’s a summary of those columns:

 StartTime: The starting time of the storm event.
 EndTime: The ending time of the storm event.
 EpisodeId: A unique identifier for the storm event.
 State: The state in which the storm event occurred.
 Level: A substring of the storm summary, capturing the first 100 characters.

Thus, the output will consist of these five distinct columns.
